body: Due to the ThetaForecaster's dependency on SES, #198 also (re-)implements the ExpSmoothingForecaster in the new framework.

issue.title: AutoAR forecaster

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
#220 

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Simple auto-regressive forecaster with automatic estimation of number of lags.

#### Any other comments?
Currently not working due to bug in statsmodels, wait for new release with bug fix
* issue: https://github.com/statsmodels/statsmodels/issues/6553
* merged PR: https://github.com/statsmodels/statsmodels/pull/6556
 
#### Next steps
* Merge into `master`, not `dev` (see #360)
* This should now work with the new statsmodels release https://github.com/statsmodels/statsmodels/releases/tag/v0.12.0

body: Is there a way to tune both sklearn & sktime hyperparameters at the same time, when using regressors from sklearn? If not. It could be really useful to have it.

Hi @hweiTPR, yes you can do something like this: 
```python

regressor_param_grid = {"n_estimators": [100, 200, 300]}
forecaster_param_grid = {"window_length": [10, 12, 14]}
regressor = GridSearchCV(RandomForestRegressor(), param_grid=regressor_param_grid)
forecaster = RecursiveRegressionForecaster(regressor)
cv = SlidingWindowSplitter(initial_window=100)
gscv = ForecastingGridSearchCV(forecaster, cv=cv, param_grid=forecaster_param_grid)
gscv.fit(y_train)

print(gscv.best_params_, gscv.best_forecaster_.regressor_.best_params_)
>>> {'window_length': 12} {'n_estimators': 100}
```
That looks great! Would be helpful to have this in the documentation!

@hweiTPR I mention it already in the forecasting tutorial below cell 27: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/examples/01_forecasting.ipynb but without showing the code! Would appreciate a PR if you'd like to add it! 🙂

@mloning (switching to my personal account) I totally missed that sentence. Happy to contribute. I have another question: what can I put for "score" when using ForecastingGridSearchCV? I tried smape_loss, but it threw me an error.

This should work: 
```python
from sktime.forecasting.model_selection import ForecastingGridSearchCV
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor
from sktime.forecasting.compose import RecursiveRegressionForecaster
from sktime.forecasting.model_selection import SlidingWindowSplitter
from sktime.performance_metrics.forecasting import sMAPE
from sklearn.model_selection import GridSearchCV
from sktime.datasets import load_airline

y_train = load_airline()

regressor_param_grid = {"n_estimators": [100, 200, 300]}
forecaster_param_grid = {"window_length": [10, 12, 14]}
regressor = GridSearchCV(RandomForestRegressor(), param_grid=regressor_param_grid)
forecaster = RecursiveRegressionForecaster(regressor)
cv = SlidingWindowSplitter(initial_window=100)
gscv = ForecastingGridSearchCV(forecaster, cv=cv, param_grid=forecaster_param_grid, scoring=sMAPE())
gscv.fit(y_train)
print(gscv.cv_results_)
```
This is a deviation from scikit-learn, as we encapsulated loss functions as classes rather than functions, that makes it easier to attach additional information that's needed when running GSCV. This functionality also still needs some improvements to handle multi-step forecasting horizons.

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look at
the extension guidelines: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->
Followup on comments under #220. 

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented. 
-->
Adding these code to the tutorial makes it clearer how to tune the parameters of sklearn regressors, and how to use the scoring option of ForecastingGridSearchCV. 

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one? 

<!--
If your contribution does add a new dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate
 companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum. 
-->
Nope.

#### PR checklist for new estimators 
<!--
This is only relevant if you contribute a new estimator
 (classifiers, regressors, forecasters, etc
.). If so, please go through the checklist below. Otherwise please ignore check list.

- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally. 
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.
- [ ] I've updated sktime's [estimator overview](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/ESTIMATOR_OVERVIEW.md) and I'm committed to maintain my contribution and provide bug fixes if necessary.
- [ ] I've added myself to the list of contributors
-->

#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.

Thanks for contributing!
-->

issue.title: Add date-time support for forecasting framework

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
#347, #220

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
* Support for `pd.DatetimeIndex`, `pd.PeriodIndex` in data and forecasting horizon, including helper functions to patch mathematical operations on pandas date/time objects for our purposes (mostly returning integers for known time unit, rather than time delta objects)
* Included forecasting data sets are now returned with `pd.PeriodIndex`
* Support for absolute forecasting horizon specification via refactored `ForecastingHorizon` class
* Easy importing via `sktime.forecasting.all` module enabling `from sktime.forecasting.all import *` following [fastai](https://www.fast.ai/2020/02/13/fastai-A-Layered-API-for-Deep-Learning/)
* A few minor changes (typos, formatting, etc)
* Corresponding updates to forecasting notebook
* New unit tests for supported combinations of data index types and forecasting types

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one? 
* seaborn (soft dependency, for plotting) 

#### Key files to review 
Since the forecasting horizon was used in basically every forecasting algorithm, this PR makes changes to many files. Key changes include:

* `sktime/forecasting/base/_fh.py` (implementation of forecasting horizon class)
* `sktime/forecasting/base/tests/test_fh.py` (unit tests for forecasting horizon class)
* `sktime/forecasting/tests/_config.py` (check SUPPORTED_INDEX_FH_COMBINATIONS)
* `sktime/forecasting/tests/test_all_forecasters.py` (unit testing framework for all forecasters)
* `sktime/utils/datetime.py` (date/time helper functions)

#### Comments
* Supporting only `pd.PeriodIndex` and not `pd.DatetimeIndex` would make the code a bit simpler as `pd.DatetimeIndex` requires additional patches to return integers for durations/time deltas and additional type distinctions (dispatch), however it seems like `pd.DatetimeIndex` supports some functionality which is not supported by `pd.PeriodIndex` (e.g. `is_month_end`)

#### Future work
* refactor `BaseLastWindowForecaster` and reduce inheritance as much as possible

issue.title: Is there any imputation method in sktime?

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body: Currently, I'm encountering a prediction problem with some missing values. In the current implementation of sktime, when there is a missing value in the timing window, sktime will output nan. However, rather than tuning the size of the timing window, I prefer to fill these missing values. Thus, is there any method to do so?
